article.description: Curtis Stinson scored 19 points and led a rally that brought Iowa State from 13 down in the second half to an 83-77 victory over Colorado on Wednesday night.
article.headline: Iowa State rallies from 13 down
article.linkText: Cyclones seriously damage Buffs' NCAA hopes
article.story: AMES, Iowa (AP) -- Between Marcus Jefferson and its second-half press, Iowa State was full of surprises for Colorado. Colorado unraveled against Iowa State's pressure and the Cyclones came from 13 down to pull out an 83-77 victory on Wednesday night and send their seniors off in fine fashion. "I don't think Colorado was prepared for the pressure," Jefferson said. "They turned the ball over and that right there basically is what won the game for us." Freshman Curtis Stinson and senior Jackson Vroman, playing his final regular-season game at home, led Iowa State (16-10, 7-8) with 19 points. But Jefferson, another senior, was huge with 15 points on 5-for-7 shooting, three steals and two assists. Jefferson, whose mother died last May, left the team for three weeks in February to deal with some personal matters. Wednesday night was his third game back and he had his best performance since scoring 16 in the season opener against Mercer. "I had my mom on my mind tonight," Jefferson said. "I just went out and played hard so we could get a win." Jefferson had been averaging just 5.8 points. "I think it kind of caught people off guard a little bit, him being gone for that long," Iowa State's Jake Sullivan said. "They gave him some good looks at the start of the game and he knocked them down." Colorado (17-9, 9-6) took control early with torrid outside shooting. The Buffaloes made their first eight 3-point attempts and shot 62 percent in the first half before cooling to 37.5 percent in the second half, when Iowa State began pressing. And then there were the turnovers -- 26 in all as Iowa State came up with 16 steals. "It was a hell of a press," Colorado's David Harrison said. "That press slowed down our offense and got them back in the game." Michel Morandais hit a career-high five 3-pointers and led Colorado with 17 points, but he went scoreless after his 3 gave the Buffaloes a 56-43 lead with 17:12 left. The turnovers negated Colorado's 38-21 rebounding advantage. "Twenty-six turnovers, that speaks for itself," Colorado coach Ricardo Patton said. "You can't win on the road turning it over 26 times. I think our guys panicked." Stinson's driving shot capped a 7-0 run that gave Iowa State its first lead, 62-61, with 10:17 remaining. The lead then changed hands three times before Iowa State went ahead to stay with a 9-1 burst that made it 78-72 with 3:08 to play. The key basket in that run was a 3 by Sullivan, who scored 12 points. Jefferson drove to the basket and fired an underhand pass toward the left corner to Sullivan, who buried the shot to make it 75-71. "It kind of capped everything off for us, two seniors making a play," Sullivan said. "It was a great way to really end this thing, a great win." Iowa State secured the victory by sinking five of six free throws in the final 1:28. The Cyclones were leading 80-77 when Vroman drew a charging foul on Chris Copeland. Will Blalock followed with two free throws, after which Jefferson stole the ball back and made a final free throw. "What I'm happiest about in this win is the fact we sent our seniors off the way we sent them off, in front of a great crowd at Hilton," Iowa State coach Wayne Morgan said. "I think it's a memory that not only they can cherish for the rest of their lives, I think we all can." Harrison added 16 points for Colorado, which had won four straight and was hoping to stay in contention for an NCAA tournament berth. The Buffaloes finish the regular season at home Saturday against Nebraska. "They're all must wins," Harrison said. "We don't have the name of Kansas or a coach like quote, Bobby Knight, unquote that they want in the tournament. We have to show the selection committee that 10 wins in our conference is big."
